newsitem.title: USA: Gingrich backs family programs on prime time TV.
newsitem.headline: Gingrich backs family programs on prime time TV.

text.p: House Speaker Newt Gingrich urged the television networks Thursday to re-establish family programming during the first hour of prime time each night.

Gingrich, a Georgia Republican, said the networks used to reserve the first hour of nightly programing for shows like "Happy Days," "Little House on the Prairie" and the "Cosby Show" suitable for all viewers.

"This voluntary covenant with the viewing public has disintegrated to the point where the former family hour now features sitcoms and dramas promoting promiscuity and obscene language," Gingrich said in a letter to the presidents of the major TV networks.

"By creating a safe haven for the family viewing audience, and resolving to dedicate one hour of prime time programming to the promotion of positive values, the entertainment industry would not only endear itself to parents, but also immeasurablely benefit American society," he said.

Gingrich said more than 100 members of Congress from both parties were sending similar letters to the networks. Their names will be published in an advertisement Friday in the entertainment industry newspaper Daily Variety.
